questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with developmental delays, including difficulties in motor coordination and speech. MRI reveals a complete absence of the corpus callosum. Which of the following is not typically associated with this condition?
Which of the following is part of the complete syndrome triad associated with Anterior Choroidal Artery Syndrome?
The labyrinthine artery arises from which of the following arteries?
In the image below, which structure is labeled as the rostrum of the corpus callosum?

A 35 year old patient presents with rapid weight gain and persistent hunger despite adequate food intake. MRI reveals a lesion in the hypothalamus. Which of the following hypothalamic nuclei, when lesioned, is most likely to cause an uncontrolled appetite and extreme obesity?
questions.explanation:
Area/Nuclei

Function

Lesion

Anterior Hypothalamic Area & Preoptic Area (Option A)

Influences parasympathetic responses (e.g., lowers blood pressure, slows heart rate, heat regulation)

Can disrupt thermoregulation and lead to hyperthermia.

Posterior & Lateral Nuclei

Mediates sympathetic responses (e.g., increases blood pressure, accelerates heart rate, cold regulation).

May cause impaired sympathetic responses and issues with stress response.

Lateral Hypothalamus (Option C)

Acts as the hunger & thirst centre; stimulates food intake.

Leads to anorexia and significant weight loss.

Medial Hypothalamus- Ventromedial nucleus

Acts as the satiety centre; inhibits eating.

Causes uncontrolled appetite and extreme obesity.

Supraoptic & Paraventricular Nuclei

Secretes vasopressin and oxytocin; regulates water balance and reproductive functions.

Can disrupt water balance and lead to diabetes insipidus.

Suprachiasmatic Nucleus (Option D)

Regulates circadian rhythms and biological clocks.

Can disrupt sleep-wake cycles and lead to insomnia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the function of the Ventral Posteromedial Nucleus within the Ventral Group Nuclei?

options.label: A
options.text: Influences motor activities by connecting with the premotor cortex.

options.label: B
options.text: Receives sensory information from the cerebellum and red nucleus.

options.label: D
options.text: Projects to the primary motor areas of the cerebral cortex.

questions.correct_answer: C. Receives trigeminal and gustatory pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following thalamic nuclei is concerned with recent memory and emotional tone?
questions.explanation:
Anterior part

Medial part

Lateral part
  • Contains anterior thalamic nuclei.
  • Receives mammillothalamic tract from mammillary nuclei.
  • Reciprocal connections with cingulate gyrus and hypothalamus.
  • Functions related to the limbic system.
  • Concerned with emotional tone and recent memory.
  • It is a part of the Papez circuit
  • Contains the large dorsomedial nucleus and smaller nuclei.
  • Two-way connections with prefrontal cortex and hypothalamic nuclei.
  • Interconnected with all other thalamic nuclei.
  • Responsible for integrating sensory (somatic, visceral, olfactory) information with emotional and subjective states. (Option C)
  • Subdivided into dorsal and ventral tiers.

Dorsal Tier:

  • Includes lateral dorsal nucleus, lateral posterior nucleus, and pulvinar.
  • Interconnections with other thalamic nuclei, parietal lobe, cingulate gyrus, occipital, and temporal lobes.

Ventral Tier:

  • Nuclei arranged in a craniocaudal sequence
  • Further divided into ventral anterior, ventral posterior and ventral lateral nuclei

questions.text: A 62 year old patient presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and facial droop. Neurological examination reveals upper motor neuron signs with weakness in both the arm and leg on the right side. MRI confirms an infarct in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory involving the genu of the internal capsule. Which of the following tracts passes through the genu?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Supplies

Tracts Affected in Lesions

Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)
  • The ventral part of the anterior limb

Corticopontine tract affecting communication between cortex and cerebellum

Heubner's Artery
  • Ventral anterior limb

Corticopontine and frontopontine tracts: Impaired voluntary movements.

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
  • Parts of the anterior limb
  • Genu
  • Posterior limb

Corticobulbar tract (genu): Facial muscle weakness and motor deficits in cranial nerves

Corticospinal tract (posterior limb): Contralateral limb weakness or paralysis (Option B)

Internal Carotid Artery (ICA)

-

Varies depending on perforator origin, affecting similar tracts as MCA and AChA supplies

Anterior Choroidal Artery (AChA)
  • Ventral posterior limb
  • Retro-lenticular 
  • Sub-lenticular portions

Corticospinal tract (posterior limb): Contralateral motor deficits

Optic radiations (retro-lenticular part): Visual field defects

Auditory radiations (sub lenticular part): Auditory processing issues

questions.text: Which of the following tracts passes through the genu of the internal capsule?
questions.explanation:
Anterior limb

Retrolentiform part

Sublentiform part
  • Frontopontine fibres (Arnold's bundle)
  • Corticorubral fibres
  • Parietopontine,occipitopontine, and occipitotectal fibres
  • Optic radiation (Option C)
  • Temporopontine fibres
  • Auditory radiation (fibres from the medial geniculate body to the auditory cortex) (Option D)
  • Thalamic fibres to the temporal cortex and amygdala.

questions.text: Which sulcus is involved in separating the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe?
questions.explanation:
Lateral View

Medial View

  • Central Sulcus: Divides the frontal lobe (anterior) from the parietal lobe (posterior).
  • Lateral Sulcus: Distinguishes the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes.
  • Pre-central Gyrus: Located in front of the central sulcus; it contains the frontal motor cortex, which controls skeletal muscles.
  • Post-central Gyrus: Located behind the central sulcus; houses the parietal sensory cortex for general sensations (touch, pain, temperature, proprioception).
  • Insula: Found in the floor of the lateral sulcus.
  • Central Sulcus: Separates the frontal motor cortex (pre-central gyrus) from the parietal sensory cortex.
  • Paracentral Lobule: Controls the contralateral lower limb, pelvis, and perineum.
  • Calcarine Sulcus: Associated with the occipital visual cortex.
  • Limbic Lobe: Involved in emotions and memory.
  • Cingulate Gyrus: An arch-shaped convolution above the corpus callosum.

Layer

Function

I- Molecular layer

Receives nonspecific input signals from lower brain centers.
Control the excitability of stimulated areas.

II- External granular layer

Receives nonspecific input and sends axons to the opposite cortex through the corpus callosum.

III- External pyramidal layer

Sends axons to related cortical areas on the opposite side through the corpus callosum.

The outer band of Baillarger is a part of this layer of cerebral cortex, specifically located in the motor cortex and somatosensory cortex.

IV- Internal granular layer

The primary layer for receiving input sensory signals, which then spread to the surface and deeper layers.

V- Internal pyramidal layer

Sends large axons to distant nervous system parts like basal ganglia, brain stem, and spinal cord.
Controls signal transmission.

VI- Fusiform/ polymorphic layer

Sends axons to the thalamus.

Regulates excitability of incoming sensory signals.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the anatomical relations of the internal capsule?

options.label: A
options.text: The anterior limb lies between the thalamus and the posterior part of the lentiform nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: The genu is located posterior to the head of the caudate nucleus.

options.label: C
options.text: The medial boundary consists of the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.

options.label: D
options.text: The retro lentiform part is situated above the lentiform nucleus.

questions.correct_answer: C. The medial boundary consists of the thalamus and the caudate nucleus.

options.label: A
options.text: A-Putamen; B- Globus Pallidus; C- Caudate Nucleus; D- Subthalamic Nucleus; E- Substantia Nigra; F- Thalamus

options.label: B
options.text: A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Thalamus; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra

options.label: C
options.text: A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Globus Pallidus; C- Substantia Nigra; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Thalamus; F- Subthalamic Nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Globus Pallidus; D- Thalamus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra

questions.correct_answer: B. A- Caudate Nucleus; B- Putamen; C- Thalamus; D- Globus Pallidus; E- Subthalamic Nucleus; F- Substantia Nigra

questions.text: A 70 year old female presents with tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Neurological examination reveals degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in a specific region of the brain. Which component of the basal ganglia is primarily affected in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Component

Location

Role/Function

Caudate Nucleus

(Option A)

Near the thalamus and internal capsule

C-shaped structure; contributes to lateral ventricle floor; forms the striatum with the putamen; receives cortical input.

Putamen

(Option B)

Basal forebrain, close to claustrum

Part of the corpus striatum; receives input from various cortical areas and is involved in motor control.

Globus Pallidus

(Option D)

Basal ganglia; divided into internal and external segments

The primary output nucleus; is involved in movement control pathways (direct and indirect).

Subthalamic Nucleus

Diencephalon

Receives input from external globus pallidus; projects to internal globus pallidus; uses glutamate (excitatory neurotransmitter) as part of the indirect pathway. Lesions in STN lead to hemiballismus.

Substantia Nigra

Midbrain; divided into pars compacta and pars reticulata

Produces dopamine (crucial for smooth, coordinated movements); degeneration of neurons in pars compacta is implicated in Parkinson's disease.

Nucleus Accumbens

Ventral striatum

Involved in reward, motivation, and addiction; linked to the brain's reward circuitry.

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents with fluent but nonsensical speech and difficulty understanding spoken language. He is unaware of his language difficulties, and his reading and writing abilities are also severely impaired. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Characteristics

Global Aphasia

(Option A)

Most severe form; few recognizable words, little/no comprehension

Common after stroke; may improve if brain damage is limited

Broca's Aphasia

(Option B)

Non-fluent aphasia

Severely reduced speech output; can't speak fluently; short utterances (≤ 4 words)

Good comprehension, poor writing; speech is laborious

Wernicke's Aphasia

(Option C)

Fluent aphasia

Impaired comprehension; fluent but nonsensical speech

Speech filled with jargon; severe reading/writing issues

Anomic Aphasia

(Option D)

Difficulty finding correct nouns/verbs.

Fluent speech, speech filled with vague words; good comprehension/reading.

Conduction Aphasia

Damage to the arcuate fasciculus, a white matter tract connecting the Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas.

Difficulty repeating sentences, trouble using phonemes correctly, and impaired ability to name objects.

Language production and auditory comprehension are largely intact.

Primary Progressive Aphasia

Gradual decline in language skills due to neurodegenerative diseases.

Slow progression in speech, comprehension, reading, and writing.

Mixed Non-fluent Aphasia

Similar to severe Broca's but with limited comprehension

Sparse, effortful speech; basic reading/writing skills

questions.text: Match the Brodmann areas with their respective functions: Brodmann Area Function a) BA 1, 2, 3 1) Primary visual cortex b) BA 4 2) Primary motor cortex c) BA 17 3) Primary somatosensory cortex d) BA 44, 45 4) Language production (Broca’s area)
questions.explanation:
Brodmann’s numbers

Function

Location

BA 1, 2, 3
  • Primary Somatosensory Cortex
  • Processes tactile information from the body.

Postcentral gyrus.

BA 4
  • Primary Motor Cortex
  • Controls voluntary movements via corticospinal and cortico-nuclear tracts.

Precentral gyrus.

BA 8

  • Prefrontal Cortex
  • Involved in planning and decision-making.

The anterior part of the frontal lobe.

BA 17

  • Primary Visual Cortex (V1)
  • Processes visual information from the lateral geniculate nucleus.

Occipital lobe (calcarine sulcus, cuneus, and lingual gyrus).

BA 22
  • Language comprehension (Wernicke’s area)

Superior temporal gyrus

BA 41
  • Primary auditory cortex

Superior temporal gyrus

BA 42
  • Secondary auditory cortex

Adjacent to BA 41

BA 44 and 45
  • Broca’s area
  • Speech production.
  • BA 44 (Opercular part): Syntactic processing (grammar).
  • BA 45 (Triangular part): Semantic processing (meaning).
  • Left BA 44 is typically larger, reflecting language dominance.

Inferior frontal gyrus of the frontal lobe.

questions.text: A 68 year old male presents with sudden onset weakness in his right arm and face, along with difficulty speaking. MRI reveals an ischemic stroke. Which artery is most likely involved in this patient’s stroke based on his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Surface Type

Major Artery Supplied By

Lateral Surface

Middle cerebral artery (primary), anterior cerebral artery (superomedial border), posterior cerebral artery (occipital lobe, inferior temporal gyrus)

Medial & Inferior Surface

Anterior cerebral artery (largest area), middle cerebral artery (temporal pole, orbital surface), posterior cerebral artery (remaining areas)

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the representation of body parts in the motor and sensory homunculi?

options.label: A
options.text: In the motor homunculus, finer motor control areas like arms and legs have larger cortical regions.

options.label: B
options.text: The sensory homunculus shows body parts with higher acuity, like fingertips, having smaller cortical areas.

options.label: C
options.text: Both homunculi are in the precentral gyrus and represent the same body parts.

options.label: D
options.text: The motor homunculus in the precentral gyrus has larger areas for fine motor parts like hands and face.

questions.correct_answer: D. The motor homunculus in the precentral gyrus has larger areas for fine motor parts like hands and face.
